title: Why the debt markets are giving the world’s strongmen a boost
description: Take a glance at bond prices in China and India and you will see a strikingly different picture to what is happening in Britain and France.
content:
Take a glance at bond prices in China and India and you will see a strikingly different picture to what is happening in Britain and France.

Governments in Beijing and New Delhi have seen borrowing costs fall in recent years. By contrast, Western economies have endured rising bond yields as the costs of servicing national debts have hit levels not seen since the aftermath of the global financial crisis.

On Monday, images of a laughing Xi Jinping, Narendra Modi and Russia’s Vladimir Putin were beamed across the world from northern China’s Tianjin region.

The trio – part of the Brics group of emerging economies – put on a show of camaraderie as they sought to cement an alliance of “strongmen” leaders who have run their countries since 2013, 2014 and 2000 respectively.

A look at the debt costs of these nations shows why they have some reason to be cheerful. China’s 30-year bond yield has fallen from around 3.4pc in 2022 to 2.06pc this week, less than half of the premium demanded by investors in British debt.

In India, equivalent yields are down from a peak of 7.88pc in 2022 to 7.26pc.

Russia maintains its international pariah status, cutting it off from the mainstream bond market. However, it has found other ways to keep money rolling in. Moscow on Tuesday announced it had agreed to supply more natural gas to China.

“Everyone is incrementally shifting their view on how the world is working,” says James Athey, a bond trader at investment manager Marlborough. “It is happening gradually and slowly in the background.”

Gordon Shannon, a portfolio manager at TwentyFour Asset Management, says the relative borrowing cost benefits being enjoyed by the likes of China are as much about Western turmoil as they are about policy in Beijing.

“I would argue the market’s preference isn’t so much for strongmen as for politicians who have the willingness and ability to cut spending,” he says.

“Over the last couple of years, the market’s willingness to overlook the unsustainable fiscal positions of developed market economies has seemingly waned significantly.”

France is on the brink of its second government collapse in less than a year after failing to pass reforms designed to cut spiralling public spending. The 30-year yield on French government debt climbed to its highest level since 2009 this week.

In Britain – even with a working majority of 156 – Sir Keir Starmer has been unable to get spending cuts past his own MPs, sending long-term UK borrowing costs surging to their highest level since 1998.

“Inflation, ballooning government debt piles to finance Covid-19 measures and a lack of political willingness to rein in spending has resulted in investors shopping globally for alternatives,” says Shannon.
summary: The bond prices in China and India are significantly different from those seen in Britain and France. These countries have seen borrowing costs fall in recent years, while Western economies have seen rising bond yields due to rising costs of servicing national debts. China's 30-year bond yield has dropped from around 3.4pc in 2022 to 2.06pc, less than half of the premium demanded by investors in British debt. Meanwhile, India's equivalent yields have dropped from a peak of 7.88pc in 2021 to 7.26pc. The relative borrowing cost benefits are due to Western turmoil as much as policy in Beijing.
shortSummary: Bond prices in China and India are giving strongmen leaders like Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin a boost, while Western economies face rising debt costs and economic challenges.
